 The tally in Florida also does not include overseas and military votes, which will like favor Bush. Kerry would basically have to win about 80% of the provisional and absentee ballots in Florida to win it, which is virtually impossible.
 
 And in Ohio, Bush is up about 130,000 votes. There are approximately 250,000 provisional ballots. Last night on tv, I heard that generally 10-15% of provisional ballots are actually counted. Even if 50% of the provisional ballots were counted, Kerry would have to win every single one to even get a 1 vote lead in Ohio. He can recount all he wants...there is no way they can allege some sort of wide-scale fraud to make up 130,000 votes.

The left really needs to take a long hard look at themselves and figure out why they are so unpopular. I hope they come to the correct conclusion (that they have moved too far away from their traditional values).

As to your unpopular remark, I thought the vote was 51/48 split between Bush and Kerry, seems there is only a narrow margin in the "popularity" stakes.

 
 
 The 51% popular vote for Bush is the highest for any presidential candidate in about 30 years. How can that be close? FL is not close at all. OH is close, but it seems like it\'s impossible for a Kerry victory. Bush was up significantly in Missouri, Colorado, and West Virginia.

Congratulations to anyone that feels like they "won" something, condolences to those that feel they "lost" something. Unfortunately, this wasn\'t a sporting event, so we all share the results equally as Americans. The reality is that the election circus is over, but we still have all the issues to deal with. We\'re still in Iraq, we\'re still in Afghanistan, we\'re still exporting jobs, gas is at record prices, medical costs are skyrocketing, terrorism is very much a reality.................................... To the victor go the spoils, lets hope America made the right decision!

 Actually, I was not in the least surprised. I think if you were here, especially in this lovely state of Tennessee, you would understand a little better. (Actually my county went to Kerry, but that didn't matter one bit.)
 
 There are these things called "Heartland Values" and "Wedge Issues." Republicans are the masters of using these political tools. You can rob the country blind and drive it off a cliff, but if you say you are against abortion and gays being allowed to breathe, then you get massive support. 
 
 Another thing to remember. There was one real issue that trumped all others, and that's Iraq, of course. If anyone was truly against the war, they had to convince themselves that Kerry was against it too. Despite what he says and how he tries to make people forget it, he voted for it. So, if your main issue was being against the war in Iraq, you didn't have a candidate in this election (why I didn't even vote). Something like 40% of people voting "for" Kerry were doing so to vote against Bush. I think most of the people that could see Kerry for the pandering douche that he was just stayed home (actually, I went to a Ministry concert that totally ruled). 
 
 So, as incomprehensible as it may seem to outsiders, there are very easy explanations as to why Bush won.

Own a business, make a fortune off the ignorant masses, who are kept more ignorant by faith-based-reasoning (a good thing for any business owner), enjoy Bush giving you tax cuts even thought the nation cannot afford them, retire early and kick back as the king of a little kingdom, for the most part unaffected by the woes of the common sheep. Basically take advantage of the ignorant masses that fuel your anger. That is of course, what happens to the ignorant, to not take advantage of them would be unamerican. If America's government or lack thereof spirals out of control because the dumb get dumber and corruption runs rampant, you'll have enough cash to live like a king in most any country..except maybe Japan ;)

Bush one because of one principle, trust. the voters trusted Bush to do what he said he would and didn't trust Kerry to do the same. Amongst voters who identified moral values as a big factor, Bush won handily.

 
 That's interesting.
 
 Voted for Bush, a wealthy politician, moved into running for governor by a political consultant (Rove), then pushed to run for President (Rove runs a super game), as part of an administration known fondly as the Mayberry Machievelli's (!)......based on TRUST? MORAL VALUES?
 What about the economy, terrorism, honesty (WMDs), responsibility (Tax cuts during a war), leadership? 
 
 Trust and moral values?
 
 That's so wrong and ironic on so many levels, but darn it all if Rove didn't know exactly the dumb-buttons to press on. 
 
 Exactly what evidence did we have that Bush was trustworthy. His word?
 
 
 "Make no mistake about it: We are winning and we will win,"
 "We will win by staying on the offensive
 
 vs
 
 acceptance speech Thursday night. He said that "in this different kind of war, we may never sit down at a peace table." 
 Asked about "this war on terror" during that interview, Bush said: "I don't think you can win it.
 ===================
 
 The most important thing is for us to find Osama bin Laden. It is our number one priority and we will not rest until we find him."
 - G.W. Bush, 9/13/01
 
 "I want justice...There's an old poster out West, as I recall, that said, 'Wanted: Dead or Alive,'"
 - G.W. Bush, 9/17/01, UPI
 
 vs
 
 
 "I don't know where bin Laden is. I have no idea and really don't care. It's not that important. It's not our priority."
 - G.W. Bush, 3/13/02
 
 "I am truly not that concerned about him."
 - G.W. Bush, repsonding to a question about bin Laden's whereabouts, 
 3/13/02 (The New American, 4/8/02) 
 http://www.buzzflash.com/contributors/2002/11/13_Laden.html

 there as been a loss of 1 million jobs.

Yes. I must say it is amazing how our two cultures can produce such different mind sets in such a small period of time. And people claim that the west doesn't understand the eastern mindset, hell, we don't even understand each others! 
 
 I mean the US has only really been a separate culture for a couple of centuries, a tiny proportion of any nation in Europe's history. Yet our culture has already grown so remarkably apart. A man like Bush wouldn't even get a look in over here. Electing him in the first place is understandable, a few always slip through the net so to speak, but what really baffles us is why any sane person would want him back again. But yeah, I guess we really have grown apart. 
 
 Such a shame that a country that was founded as the bastion of enlightenment in the western world can so quickly be overtaken by the very regime it split from.

 You can't wave a wand and poof! 6 million new jobs are created. That's what Kerry would have you believe though. Bush realized that all a President can do is create an environment in which business can grow. Contrast that with Kerry's plan to take back the tax cuts given to small businesses making over $200K. I'm sure that'll grow the largest segment of job creation. emoticon_rolleyes Yes. Trust and Moral Values. :)
